items.title: Trump and Putin set to meet without President Zelensky present
items.standfirst: US President Donald Trump and his Russian counterpart Vladimir Putin meet in Alaska today for critical talks on the war in Ukraine. Ahead of the summit, Trump alluded to a possible “swapping of territories” as part of a larger ceasefire deal, but neither Russia nor Ukraine is interested in ceding land. Here is what you need to know about the key regions in Ukraine claimed by Russia. France24 Correspondent Emmanuelle Chaze reports from Kyiv.

items.title: Trump and Putin set for high-stakes Alaska summit amid Ukraine tensions
items.standfirst: Donald Trump is traveling to Alaska for high-stakes talks with Russian President Vladimir Putin over the war in Ukraine, marking their first one-on-one meeting in six years. Posting “HIGH STAKES!!!” on Truth Social, the U.S. president has amplified expectations and a sense of drama, according to correspondents. Russia’s foreign minister insists Moscow’s stance remains “clear and unambiguous,” while Ukraine’s President Volodymyr Zelensky—excluded from the talks—has warned that any decisions made without him will be meaningless. We discuss the implications with former White House Director of European Affairs Anthony Gardner.
items.content: Donald Trump is traveling to Alaska for high-stakes talks with Russian President Vladimir Putin over the war in Ukraine, marking their first one-on-one meeting in six years. Posting “HIGH STAKES!!!” on Truth Social, the U.S. president has amplified expectations and a sense of drama, according to correspondents. Russia’s foreign minister insists Moscow’s stance remains “clear and unambiguous,” while Ukraine’s President Volodymyr Zelensky—excluded from the talks—has warned that any decisions made without him will be meaningless. We discuss the implications with former White House Director of European Affairs Anthony Gardner.

items.title: Trump leaves on Air Force One to meet Putin for Ukraine talks in Alaska
items.standfirst: US President Donald Trump insisted Thursday he would not be intimidated by Russia's Vladimir Putin ahead of a rare, high-stakes summit on Ukraine in Alaska on Friday that marks Putin’s first visit to Western soil since the 2022 invasion. The summit comes as Moscow made fresh battlefield gains and Kyiv warned of a “personal victory” for the Kremlin leader. Charlotte Lam tells us more.
items.content: US President Donald Trump insisted Thursday he would not be intimidated by Russia's Vladimir Putin ahead of a rare, high-stakes summit on Ukraine in Alaska on Friday that marks Putin’s first visit to Western soil since the 2022 invasion. The summit comes as Moscow made fresh battlefield gains and Kyiv warned of a “personal victory” for the Kremlin leader. Charlotte Lam tells us more.

items.title: Putin ready to make Ukraine deal, Trump says before Alaska summit
items.standfirst: US president’s comment that Russian and Ukrainian leaders may have to ‘divvy’ things up likely to raise alarmDonald Trump has said he believes Vladimir Putin is ready to make a deal on the war in Ukraine as the two leaders prepare for their summit in Alaska on Friday, but his suggestion that the Russian leader and Volodymyr Zelenskyy could “divvy things up” may alarm some in Kyiv.The US president, who left the White House on Friday at 7.30am, implied there was a 75% chance of the Alaska meeting succeeding, and that the threat of economic sanctions may have made Putin more willing to seek an end to the war. “HIGH STAKES!!!” he posted on Truth Social as his motorcade idled outside the White House shortly after sunrise in Washington. Continue reading...

Continue reading...

The summit comes as Moscow made fresh battlefield gains and Kyiv warned of a “personal victory” for the Kremlin leader. Senior Analyst at European Union Institute for Security Studies, Ondrej Ditrych, joins us for further explanations.

items.title: Washington DC sues after Trump officials’ ‘hostile takeover’ of city police
items.standfirst: Pam Bondi says DEA chief Terry Cole in charge of Metropolitan police amid White House crackdown on crimeWashington DC was seeking an emergency restraining order on Friday against Donald Trump’s takeover of its police department, dubbing it a “hostile takeover” of law enforcement in the nation’s capital.The District of Columbia attorney general, Brian Schwalb, filed a lawsuit on Friday morning, hours after the US attorney general, Pam Bondi, late on Thursday issued an order for the federal government to impose a new police chief on the city’s Metropolitan police department (MPD). Continue reading...

items.title: Trump administration names DEA head to be D.C.'s emergency police commissioner

items.content: Attorney General Pam Bondi has named the head of the Drug Enforcement Administration to be Washington D.C.'s emergency police commissioner. The National Guard, FBI and other entities are now working to follow President Trump's directive to clean up the nation's capital.

clusters.title: How the world is reacting to Israel’s settlement plan in occupied West Bank
clusters.neutral_headline: Israeli settlement plan West Bank Palestinian state concerns
bullet_summary: Far-right Israeli minister Bezalel Smotrich announced approval for 3,401 new homes in the controversial E1 area project in the occupied West Bank
Israel's far-right finance minister has announced plans to build a new settlement in the Israeli-occupied West Bank, which he said would "bury" the idea of a Palestinian state

items.title: How the world is reacting to Israel’s settlement plan in occupied West Bank
items.standfirst: Plans to develop the illegal E1 settlement, which would jeopardise a future Palestinian state, widely condemned.
items.content: Plans to develop the illegal E1 settlement, which would jeopardise a future Palestinian state, widely condemned.

items.title: Israeli minister announces settlement plan to 'bury the idea of a Palestinian state'
items.standfirst: Israel’s far-right finance minister on Thursday announced plans to revive a contentious settlement plan in the occupied West Bank, which Palestinians and rights groups fear will scuttle plans for a future Palestinian state. The so-called E1 scheme linking Jerusalem and the Maale Adumim settlement has been frozen for decades amid international opposition, including from the US. Noga Tarnopolsky reports.
items.content: Israel’s far-right finance minister on Thursday announced plans to revive a contentious settlement plan in the occupied West Bank, which Palestinians and rights groups fear will scuttle plans for a future Palestinian state. The so-called E1 scheme linking Jerusalem and the Maale Adumim settlement has been frozen for decades amid international opposition, including from the US. Noga Tarnopolsky reports.

items.title: Israeli settlement plans will 'bury' idea of Palestinian state, minister says
items.standfirst: Far-right Israeli minister Bezalel Smotrich announced approval for 3,401 new homes in the controversial E1 area project in the occupied West Bank.
items.content: Far-right Israeli minister Bezalel Smotrich announced approval for 3,401 new homes in the controversial E1 area project in the occupied West Bank.

items.title: Israel appears set to approve illegal 3,400-home West Bank settlement
items.standfirst: Finance minister Bezalel Smotrich has said he believes E1 plan will ‘bury the idea of a Palestinian state’Israel appears set to give formal planning approval to a highly controversial and illegal project for more than 3,400 new homes that has been frozen for decades and which critics say would split the occupied West Bank in half.Strongly opposed by the international community, the so-called E1 plan would extend the existing Jewish settlement of Ma’ale Adumim towards Jerusalem, further cutting occupied east Jerusalem from the West Bank, and further separating the north and south of the territory. Continue reading...
items.content: Finance minister Bezalel Smotrich has said he believes E1 plan will ‘bury the idea of a Palestinian state’Israel appears set to give formal planning approval to a highly controversial and illegal project for more than 3,400 new homes that has been frozen for decades and which critics say would split the occupied West Bank in half.Strongly opposed by the international community, the so-called E1 plan would extend the existing Jewish settlement of Ma’ale Adumim towards Jerusalem, further cutting occupied east Jerusalem from the West Bank, and further separating the north and south of the territory. Continue reading...

items.title: Smotrich says new Israeli settlement ‘definitively buries the idea of a Palestinian state’
items.standfirst: Israel’s far-right Finance Minister, Bezalel Smotrich announced work would begin on the long-delayed Maale Adumim settlement in the occupied West Bank, leaving European leaders no Palestinian state to recognize. The plan had been coordinated with the Trump administration, he added.
items.content: Israel’s far-right Finance Minister, Bezalel Smotrich announced work would begin on the long-delayed Maale Adumim settlement in the occupied West Bank, leaving European leaders no Palestinian state to recognize. The plan had been coordinated with the Trump administration, he added.

• Plan could hinder future Palestinian state

items.title: Far-right Israeli minister taunts jailed Palestinian leader in prison visit
items.standfirst: Itamar Ben-Gvir posts video footage showing him making threatening remarks to a gaunt Marwan BarghoutiIsrael’s national security minister, Itamar Ben-Gvir, has posted video footage in which he is seen taunting the imprisoned Palestinian leader Marwan Barghouti in jail, prompting strong condemnation from Barghouti’s family and Palestinian leaders.The 13-second clip shows Ben-Gvir, a far-right politician on whom the UK and several other countries imposed sanctions this year for incitement to violence against Palestinians, making threatening remarks to Barghouti while Israel’s prisons minister, Kobi Yaakobi, an ally of Ben-Gvir stands nearby. Continue reading...
items.content: Itamar Ben-Gvir posts video footage showing him making threatening remarks to a gaunt Marwan BarghoutiIsrael’s national security minister, Itamar Ben-Gvir, has posted video footage in which he is seen taunting the imprisoned Palestinian leader Marwan Barghouti in jail, prompting strong condemnation from Barghouti’s family and Palestinian leaders.The 13-second clip shows Ben-Gvir, a far-right politician on whom the UK and several other countries imposed sanctions this year for incitement to violence against Palestinians, making threatening remarks to Barghouti while Israel’s prisons minister, Kobi Yaakobi, an ally of Ben-Gvir stands nearby. Continue reading...

items.title: Far-right Israeli minister taunts jailed Palestinian leader in prison visit
items.standfirst: Israel’s far-right National Security Minister Itamar Ben Gvir released a video on Friday showing him taunting Israel’s most prominent Palestinian detainee, Marwan Barghouti, a senior Fatah figure, in his jail cell. The Palestinian Authority's foreign ministry denounced the confrontation as "an unprecedented provocation". Charlotte Lam tells us more.
items.content: Israel’s far-right National Security Minister Itamar Ben Gvir released a video on Friday showing him taunting Israel’s most prominent Palestinian detainee, Marwan Barghouti, a senior Fatah figure, in his jail cell. The Palestinian Authority's foreign ministry denounced the confrontation as "an unprecedented provocation". Charlotte Lam tells us more.

items.title: Palestinians condemn Israel’s Ben-Gvir over Marwan Barghouti threat
items.standfirst: Palestinian officials have condemned far-right Israeli National Security Minister Itamar Ben-Gvir’s taunting visit to the jail cell of long-imprisoned Fatah leader Marwan Barghouti. Footage of the visit shared on social media on Thursday showed the minister making threatening remarks to the 66-year-old. France24 Noga Tarnopolsky reports the latest.

items.title: Plastic pollution treaty talks in Geneva end without an agreement
items.standfirst: Nations worked for 11 days at the United Nations office to try to complete a landmark treaty to end the plastic pollution crisis.
items.content: Nations worked for 11 days at the United Nations office to try to complete a landmark treaty to end the plastic pollution crisis.

items.title: Failed plastics negotiations in Geneva leave world few options to confront growing pollution crisis
items.standfirst: Talks on a treaty to address the global crisis of plastic pollution in Geneva ended without an agreement Friday
items.content: Talks on a treaty to address the global crisis of plastic pollution in Geneva ended without an agreement Friday

items.title: Global plastic talks collapse as countries remain deeply divided
items.standfirst: Global talks to develop a landmark treaty to end plastic pollution have once again failed. The UN negotiations, the sixth round of talks in just under three years, were due to end on Thursday but countries continued to negotiate into the night in the hopes of breaking a deadlock. Peter O'Brien tells us more.
items.content: Global talks to develop a landmark treaty to end plastic pollution have once again failed. The UN negotiations, the sixth round of talks in just under three years, were due to end on Thursday but countries continued to negotiate into the night in the hopes of breaking a deadlock. Peter O'Brien tells us more.

items.title: Global plastic talks collapse as countries remain deeply divided
items.standfirst: The latest round of UN-led talks have ended in deadlock, with disputes over plastic production and recycling.
items.content: The latest round of UN-led talks have ended in deadlock, with disputes over plastic production and recycling.

items.title: Geneva talks on global plastic pollution treaty collapse without a deal
items.standfirst: Several delegates express dismay at the failure to break a deadlock at the sixth round of talks in under three years.
items.content: Several delegates express dismay at the failure to break a deadlock at the sixth round of talks in under three years.

items.title: Talks on landmark plastic pollution treaty end without an agreement
items.standfirst: Negotiators working on a landmark treaty to address the global crisis of plastic pollution failed to reach an agreement during talks that extended into Friday in Geneva.
items.content: Negotiators working on a landmark treaty to address the global crisis of plastic pollution failed to reach an agreement during talks that extended into Friday in Geneva.

items.title: UN plastic pollution treaty talks extended by a day as no agreement reached
items.standfirst: Widely rejected draft text does not limit plastic production or address chemicals used in plastic products. Yuka Royer explains.
items.content: Widely rejected draft text does not limit plastic production or address chemicals used in plastic products. Yuka Royer explains.

clusters.ai_summary:
• Global plastic pollution treaty talks failed
• Negotiations ended without a final agreement
• Countries remained deeply divided on key issues
• Talks lasted eleven days in Geneva
• Draft text lacked limits on plastic production

items.content: Ricky Jones denied encouraging violent disorder after comments at a counter-protest last year.

items.title: Suspended Labour councillor found not guilty of encouraging violent disorder
items.standfirst: Ricky Jones was filmed speaking at anti-racism rally after last summer’s far-right riots that followed Southport murdersA suspended Labour councillor who called at an anti-racism rally for far-right activists’ throats to be cut has been found not guilty of encouraging violent disorder.Ricky Jones, 58, used the phrase “disgusting Nazi fascists” in a speech about last summer’s far-right protests after the Southport murders, his trial at Snaresbrook crown court heard. Continue reading...
items.content: Ricky Jones was filmed speaking at anti-racism rally after last summer’s far-right riots that followed Southport murdersA suspended Labour councillor who called at an anti-racism rally for far-right activists’ throats to be cut has been found not guilty of encouraging violent disorder.Ricky Jones, 58, used the phrase “disgusting Nazi fascists” in a speech about last summer’s far-right protests after the Southport murders, his trial at Snaresbrook crown court heard. Continue reading...

clusters.ai_summary:
• Councillor Ricky Jones found not guilty
• Charge was encouraging violent disorder

• Comments referred to far-right activists
• Trial took place at Snaresbrook crown court

clusters.title: Tropical storm turns into Hurricane Erin as it approaches Puerto Rico and Virgin Islands
clusters.neutral_headline: Tropical storm Erin strengthens Hurricane approaches Puerto Rico
bullet_summary: Reported by Guardian World, Al Jazeera

items.title: Tropical storm turns into Hurricane Erin as it approaches Puerto Rico and Virgin Islands
items.standfirst: Hurricane is predicted pick up steam toward Florida before veering away from the US mainlandA tropical storm sped up to become Hurricane Erin mid-morning on Friday, as it approached Puerto Rico and the Virgin Islands, bringing heavy rains that could cause flooding and landslides on its way to becoming a major Atlantic hurricane.The huge storm was swirling across the Caribbean and is ultimately expected to head towards Florida, picking up speed over warm ocean water, before ultimately veering away from the US mainland. Continue reading...
items.content: Hurricane is predicted pick up steam toward Florida before veering away from the US mainlandA tropical storm sped up to become Hurricane Erin mid-morning on Friday, as it approached Puerto Rico and the Virgin Islands, bringing heavy rains that could cause flooding and landslides on its way to becoming a major Atlantic hurricane.The huge storm was swirling across the Caribbean and is ultimately expected to head towards Florida, picking up speed over warm ocean water, before ultimately veering away from the US mainland. Continue reading...

items.title: Hurricane Erin threatens Puerto Rico, Virgin Islands with flooding
items.standfirst: Heavy rains are forecast to start with the storm expected to become a major Category 3 storm over the weekend.
items.content: Heavy rains are forecast to start with the storm expected to become a major Category 3 storm over the weekend.

clusters.ai_summary:
• Tropical storm Erin became Hurricane Erin
• Hurricane approaching Puerto Rico Virgin Islands
• Heavy rains expected causing flooding landslides
• Hurricane may strengthen further head towards Florida
• Storm expected to veer away from US mainland

clusters.title: Emmanuel Macron decries ‘antisemitic hatred’ after memorial tree cut down
clusters.neutral_headline: Macron condemns antisemitic act memorial tree felled France
bullet_summary: Reported by Guardian World, France24

items.title: Emmanuel Macron decries ‘antisemitic hatred’ after memorial tree cut down
items.standfirst: French president vows to punish those who felled tree planted in memory of Jewish man tortured to death in 2006The felling of an olive tree planted in memory of a young French Jewish man tortured to death in 2006 caused outrage in France on Friday, with Emmanuel Macron promising to punish an act of “antisemitic hatred”.Politicians across the political spectrum condemned the felling as an attack against the memory of Ilan Halimi, who was kidnapped by a gang of about 20 young people in January 2006 and tortured on a low-income housing estate in the southern Paris suburb of Bagneux. Continue reading...
items.content: French president vows to punish those who felled tree planted in memory of Jewish man tortured to death in 2006The felling of an olive tree planted in memory of a young French Jewish man tortured to death in 2006 caused outrage in France on Friday, with Emmanuel Macron promising to punish an act of “antisemitic hatred”.Politicians across the political spectrum condemned the felling as an attack against the memory of Ilan Halimi, who was kidnapped by a gang of about 20 young people in January 2006 and tortured on a low-income housing estate in the southern Paris suburb of Bagneux. Continue reading...

items.title: Macron pledges action over anti-Semitic 'hatred' after memorial tree vandalised
items.standfirst: President Emmanuel Macron on Friday condemned the felling of a memorial tree for Ilan Halimi, a Jewish man tortured to death in 2006, calling it an anti-Semitic act and vowing to punish those responsible amid rising hate crimes in France.
items.content: President Emmanuel Macron on Friday condemned the felling of a memorial tree for Ilan Halimi, a Jewish man tortured to death in 2006, calling it an anti-Semitic act and vowing to punish those responsible amid rising hate crimes in France.

clusters.ai_summary:
• Memorial tree for Ilan Halimi cut down
• Macron condemned the act as antisemitic hatred
• Tree planted in memory of a murdered Jewish man
• Politicians condemned the vandalism
• Macron vowed to punish those responsible

items.title: Flash floods kill at least 160 in Pakistan, scores still missing
items.standfirst: Sudden floods and mudslides swept through Pakistan and the disputed region of Kashmir on Thursday, killing at least 160 people, injuring more than 100 and leaving 200 missing, as rescuers searched for survivors amid the debris.
items.content: Sudden floods and mudslides swept through Pakistan and the disputed region of Kashmir on Thursday, killing at least 160 people, injuring more than 100 and leaving 200 missing, as rescuers searched for survivors amid the debris.

• Rescuers searching for survivors missing people
